Im not sure if this is a common problem with apple charging cables, but some of mine have the insulation fray closer to the connector. They still work but I worry about using them like this because I worry that the wires inside may become strained and stop working.

This is my version of a fix that has worked for me so far for about a year.

No warranty implied. Use at your own risk. etc.etc. Im just sharing what worked for me.

Print two to make.

The two halves need to be glued by superglue in order to work. The square part covers the thicker part of the cable close to the connector end. See pictures to see what I mean. Clamp as necessary.

title: Parametric Cable Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For use in electronic labs to hang all the cable somewhere accesible. But they also work great at home to tidy up all your computer cables. The idea is to print multiple and attach them next to each other to hang the cables in the gap between the hooks.
You can of course also use them as normal hooks to hang up other stuff ;)

Print some of the size you want. The 15/7mm version is intented for thicker power cables, while the 10/5mm is better for smaller cables like usb cables. Also print one endstop for the end. You can mount them directly to a wall, but I recommend to first mount them on a plank or something and bolt that to your wall. Parameters:
hook_thickness: How wide the hook is, eg. 15 or 10mm. The larger the plugs the higher you probably want this.
spacing_thickness: How wide the gap gets, eg. 7 or 5mm. Change that to best fit your cables.
extend: The length of the hook, how much it sticks out of the wall.
The rest should be fairly self explanatory.

author: Jeffreybegood

remixed_from.author: whpthomas
remixed_from.title: Fan guard retaining pin for Replicator 2

description.text:
My right extruder fan started acting like a jet engine-- spinning up slow and making a whole lot of noise. I decided to upgrade to a set of ball bearing fans. I also like Wingcommander's retaining pin, but they weren't quite the right size for this setup, so I shortened the length of the pin and rounded the cap a little. These pins hold the fan guard in place at the top of the fan where normally the holes are left empty. Orion brand fans have a good reputation on the Makerbot Operators Group so I went with those. This thing is really more of a list of part numbers for the fans and connectors so that people have a quick place to refer when ordering. All this info can be found in the Makerbot Operators Group but you have to search for it in various posts. I choose the 7CFM fan. I think even the 6CFM fan would put out more air flow than the stock fans. The stock FSY40S24M puts out 5.75CFM.
  • 1053-1208-ND FAN DC 40X10.5MM 24V 7CFM - The fan, you want 2
  • 455-2266-ND CONN HOUSING 2.5MM 2POS - The connector, they're cheap, might as well get 10
  • 455-2261-1-ND CONN TERM CRIMP XH 26-30AWG - might as well get 20 or more so when you screw up one you have more to try again.

• Disassemble your extruder fans.
  • Take your new fans and cut the wires to length using the original fans as templates for the length of the leads.
  • Strip a little off the end of the wires on your new fan leads, crimp on the connectors. If you don't have a crimp tool, you can mangle the pins with a small needle-nose pliers. If you're careful, you can use a soldering iron and some soldier.
  • Press the pins into the connector. I used a small flat head screwdriver to make sure they were fully seated. Look at the stock fan connectors to see which way the pins go into the housing.
  • Reinstall your new fans the same as the stock fans.
  • Optionally, print and install the retaining pins for the top of the fan housings. These will make it easier to take the assembly apart again in the future so that the fan guard doesn't flop around loosely.

comments.text: Couldn't be easier. Thanks for putting the info here.  Those fans are less than half as loud as the originals.

author: mater365

description.text: cross

Another fan guard design based on Crazy Jaw's Lazy Fan Guard concept. Tried a few others but none quite did it for me. With one design I still managed to destroy a fan since the holes were too big. So I wanted one that fitted snug, could be left on, even when cleaning the extruder and that didn't have too much open space in front. This one appears to give enough air intake and is very difficult to poke the allen key through.  
I printed it with 0 shells and 100% so it would be nice a solid piece. I use Sailfish on my Rep1 and turned the acceleration down a little for this print. You need support for the catches. The catches will work with the fans my Bot1 came with. These are about 10.5mm deep. The fit is snug and the 1.5mm wall thickness sandwiches this nicely in place. You may want to clean up the holes by hand with a 3mm drill bit before installing. To install, loosen the screws so the fan is free of the extruder assembly. Then tighten in place.   
I don't notice any whistling noises with this fan guard but cannot vouch for my high frequency hearing. My replacement fans seem to push more air through than the original fans and are more audible anyway.  
Designed with Cubify Invent - the best value for money in my view. Processed in Netfabb before RepG slicing. It looks the business in Fluorescent Red.

I found this awesome print in place platform jack from Thingiverse user Intentional3D http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:925556/#files.

It's a really impressive model by Intentional3D and it makes a great demonstration about how complex 3D printed parts can get, even when they are print in place designs.

comments.text: I'm new to this and trying to learn as much as I can by doing.  I printed this and it came out fine, but a few of the parts were pretty stuck to each other.  So here is what happened:  I turned the screw and the shaft snapped (I wasn't turning it hard), I used my chisel to gently try and pry the fused sections apart and I got it mostly there but then some of the structured snapped along the print lines.
comments.author: thirdhatch

comments.text: I would try to print it at 15% fill. Also, what printer are you using and with what material? Are the parts fused to each other only where the print touched the platform or was it along the length of the print?

comments.text: It's hard to tell where the fusing is occurring since I have to nearly destroy the final result in order to separate it.  I am using a wanhao i3 with a mk10 print head.  Using PLA on a .4mm extruder.

comments.text: Is it possible that the brittleness of the prints is a result of my calibration?  The sample files that came with the printer came out much better.
comments.author: thirdhatch

comments.text: Ok, I reprinted with a little more success this time.  The arms were sticking to the platform sides.  I was able to free them with judicious use of my Swiss army knife.  But the screw head broke off when I tried to turn it.  This particular malady has happened in all 3 of the prints even with a higher fill rate (20%).
comments.author: thirdhatch

comments.text:
I am sorry to hear that. 2 final suggestions;
1) try printing at 230 c with a fan blowing LIGHTLY at the printer
2) try a different filament brand: some just won't make usable prints...

This box allows you to fix the CC3D Atom board on a standard 30.5mm footprint.
It allows the routing of cables under the case.
The box is only suitable for clone CC3D Atom flight controller.
There are two different board layout on the market today. Please, refer to the attached images to determine if your flight controller is suitable.
If you have the genuine OP layout, please refer to this box http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:901880

The top cover has the LibrePilot logo.
The reason is because LibrePilot still supports CC3D/Atom.
https://forum.librepilot.org/index.php?topic=12.0

Based on Fredrik Arvidsson revonano original OpenPilot design (m-thread on forums) published here: http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=32005213&postcount=195

Print in ABS at 0.14mm, or any material which allows post processing.
The top cover holes need to be reamed to 3mm.
The holes in the bottom box must be threaded for M3 screws.

It's printed with the Zortrax M200 with Z-ABS filament.
Because of the precise tolerances required to lock the board, I have no idea how it could be with other brand printers.

author: luketanti

description.text:
Sailboat mounting system for Neopixel Strips. This project used 4-5 meter (150 per meter) WS2812B addressable LED strips. The printed brackets zip tie to the suspension cable, power cables zip tie to the bracket the LED strip hangs down below the power cables from a channel in the bracket.

I designed a bracket to attach the LEDs to the guide cord and a box to hold all the electronics, controller, fuse, and DC x DC converters.

All parts were designed in 123D. I had tried a few different designs for the brackets before coming up with one that allows gravity to face the LEDs down in relation to the suspension cord.

The system runs on 12v battery power and is controlled via a RF key fob.

I wound up using a Arduino Mega 2560 since I want to be able to expand and add control features to the system without worrying about memory space or IO pins (future expansion).

The electronics box requires no screws internally to hold the electrical components form moving. I used a combination of integrated brackets and printed parts to hold all the electronics in to minimize the need for screws.
The box top and bottom interlock and is sealed with a gasket printed in flexible filament.

While designing how the box and top will fit, I focused on one corner and modified the design and printed small test fit pieces until I found dimensions that worked, then applied that design to the rest of the box.

Parts:
4 - 5m addressable LED strips
2 - 12v x 5v DC converters (10amp max)
1 - Arduino Mega (or other Arduino compatible MC)
70' - dacron cord
1 - Inline fuse holder (25a)
1 - 12v automotive toggle switch
120+' - 10awg stranded single pair (I used UV rated low-voltage landscape wiring)
1 - screw terminal strip (8 or more terminals)

A Go PRO/FAUX extension rod for various uses. Looks solid but is not it is however extremely rigid. see instructions for other useful links and items I used.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cOzDAmDDSHH

Just to be clear I have what I call a GoFaux (trying to perpetuate a term) but I am very happy with it. This was set up to meet a need for an extremely lightweight set of extension rods for use underwater with more angle options than an extension pole. This rod is NOT solid. it is basically a 10mm x 20mm x 108mm Ibeam at a 2mm thickness that has covered sides and ends. The two holes at one end were to fill with water for neutral bouyancy but plugged they also work for weighting AND or flotation. It also turns out that this design is also free standing and stable using short thumb nuts and even more so using long thumb nuts. It has also been noted to me that this is an entirely new way to get arrested at the mall.

It turns out that the design lends itself well to use as a set for a number of other options as well as use counterweighted as a steaycam solution. use it, adapt it let me know how it works.

Use M5 25mm nutz and bolts with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537647
and it also is self standing, will securely hook on walls trees etc. Let me know.

author: laserSD

description.text:
Every maker has one of those inexpensive "helping hands" with magnifier bases. They are great except for one problem. They tip over easily. So here is a simple base to widen the footprint of the helping hands making it virtually impossible to tip over. You can simply rotate the arms 180* to remove the helping hands from the base, tool free.

I like M3-0.5 T10 screws so the arms are designed to fit the head of that screw. Most pan style head screws should work just fine.

Link to the Helping Hands used:
http://amzn.to/1TQV8rU

Link to M3-0.5 16mm T10 screws:
http://amzn.to/1OmL46g

Use M3-0.5 10 to 16mm long screws.
If you like a proud screw head, use 16mm long screws.
If you would like the screw head flush with the arm use 10mm screws and flip the arm.

You should print with supports to help the lip that holds the back of the helping hands unit in place.

Remember when tightening screws into plastic. Do not over tighten.

I created this model for my wife as she was working on a book about the Vestal Virgins: ancient Roman priestesses who dedicated their lives to watching an eternally burning fire in their temple.

Although the temple is still partially standing, it has mostly crumbled away and very little of the original building is left. Through historical research, we were able to piece together a rendition of how the temple likely looked.

I thought the temple would make a great entry into the Thingiversity Art Challenge: See The World Contest, so I tweaked the model to allow for easier printing and assembly and I am re-upload this newer version. I have also added an assembly video https://youtu.be/KYSF8zDNJPA

Enjoy.

This model has been cut into 3 separate pieces so that it can be fully printed without any supports. To join the segments together, cut 5 ½” segments of standard 1.75mm filament and place them in the internal holes that are meant to guide the three pieces together. I recommend using some cyanoacrylate glue of your choosing to bond the three pieces together (see assembly picture for information on how the three pieces fit together).

I printed this out on my Replicator 2, using Makerbot White PLA filament. I printed it with 2 shells, .2mm layer thickness and 10% infill. My wife then painted the temple to give it a little more of a realistic look.

Update 1/30/2016: Further updates to this extruder design will be published as part of the FuseBox 3D printer at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1047193 instead of this page.

V2 Update:

  • Increased tolerances for idler arm to simplify assembly
  • Tilted tensioner mount for more idler pressure

This is a super-simple, compact bowden extruder designed to use as little parts as possible. It is a direct-drive design, using an MK8 drive gear and a 625 idler bearing. This extruder has been designed to be highly accessible and easy to source; it uses just 2 bolt lengths and uses binder clip arms to tension the idler arm. With a sharp MK8 gear and 3 binder clips for tension, the extruder is strong enough to lift an entire spool of filament while printing (I found this out when my spool got tangled).

Currently, the extruder fits the 10mm bowden coupling included with E3D hotends. Additionally, the extruder mount works well with 15mm aluminum extrusion.

Bill of Materials:

  • 4 M3x10mm bolts
  • 1 M3x6mm bolt
  • 1 625 bearing
  • 2 or 3 medium-sized binder clip handles
  • 1 NEMA 17 stepper motor
  • 1 MK8 drive gear

Idler was printed at 60% infill, 3 perimeters, while the other parts were printed at 25% infill, 2 perimeters.

Very old hacky inx and python extension to convert selected path to Openscad format.
If your looking at this then dont bother, get http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036 instead.

put both files in your inkscape extension file.
Open inkscape, select a path, then go extensions>export>open scad
a dialog should pop up with the openscad code to c/p to openscad. Notes:
1) Only works on paths, so convert to shapes to paths.
2) exports as straight segments, use the add nodes extension first to increase node count to simulate curves.
3) Its very much a WIP, too busy right now to do much with it, but feel free to hack

description.text:
"Welcome, to Walt Disney's Carousel of Progress. You're in for a real treat. The Carousel of Progress was Walt's own idea from beginning to end. He loved it. He introduced the show at the World's Fair in New York City in 1964 and it was an immediate smash hit. Millions of people came to see it and since then, the Carousel of Progress has had more performances than any other stage show in the history of American theater. You know, Walt loved the idea of progress and he loved the American family. He himself was probably as American as anyone could possibly be. He thought it would be fun to watch the American family go through the twentieth century experiencing all new wonders as they came. And he put them together in a show called Carousel of Progress, which we are about to see. Although our Carousel family has experienced a few changes over the years, our show still revolves around the same theme: and that's progress. May the century begin."

This is a working model of the Carousel of Progress theater. While there is nothing on the stages (since that gets a little too detailed), it should move (I haven't printed it) and does have the correct number of seats in each of the six theaters.

This is all my own work based off of the Walt Disney Company's Carousel of Progress, with the exception of the photo (provided by Evan Wohrman's flickr, https://www.flickr.com/photos/lyght55/3352943772/in/dateposted/, CC-By-SA-2.0), as well as the gears and small hex shaft (coming from Vex Motors). I've provided a link to a model of the sign that was posted after this model.

For an explanation of what the Carousel is, here is Walt Disney himself, courtesy of Disney Parks: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qs7G_uyIK6o
And here is the pitch video to General Electric, the original sponsors of the show, courtesy of Marcio Moreira: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ERGzVsapQ54

Note: If there is interest, I may add a spot to put a Parallax Servo to drive the Carousel. Also, I may also add the eight turntables in four of the theaters if interested, as well as a way to drive the turntables.

Nothing says summer like sitting on the front porch with a friend and watching your washers catch the wind in this classic game.

Washers is a two player game of skill similar to horseshoes. The object of the game is to win (of course) by tossing your washer into the cup (located in the box): 3 points are awarded to a non-rebutted ringer (a washer in the cup; 1 point is awarded to each non-rebutted washer inside the box. Games are normally played to 21 points.

Typically the boxes are set 20 feet away from each other. However, this version is more of a "desktop version" (mostly because my printer can't print the 16 inch box, so I've scaled it down to 4 inches). However, even at 5 feet away (or less) this game will still text your washer tossing skills! Enjoy!

author: Inventor4Fun

description.text:
It is a cold sensation lamp for the warm summer nights. It is very nice in Seville (Spain) when we have to sleep with temperature over 30 degrees!

This lamp is like a snowflake and setting the iceberg color, it brings us the memories of the winter.

Furthermore, a bluetooth arduino has been integrated in order to control the LEDs and to program awesome effects like the rainbow. Thanks to the bluetooth communication, this lamp is wireless. Please, watch these videos:
Basic Control: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PX92j0QrzlE
Awesome Effects (special Christmas effect at the end of the video): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dDSM6LnCuIc
You can put over the nightstand, in the living room, or suspended from the ceiling!

In addition, an Android application has been designed to send custom commands to the snowflake lamp easily.

The final version is explained in the following lines. Later, the performed iterations and the future work to improve the lamp are described.

Recipe Ingredients:

  • Printing:

    • Transparent ABS filament (3 mm)
    • Prusa i3 steel printer
    • Repeiter-Host software using Cura slicer
    • Height layer 0.35
  • Electronic:
    • Three RGB LEDs with ws2801 controllers (http://www.ebay.es/itm/WS2801-Waterproof-IP66-12mm-LED-String-Digital-LED-pixels-Adafruit-Compat-/251997107784?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_3&hash=item3aac32b648)
    • Bluetooth Bee-Standalone (http://www.seeedstudio.com/wiki/Bluetooth_Bee-Standalone)
    • Rechargeable Battery AA 14500 900mAh Li-ion 3,6V 3,7V TrustFire UltraFire Litio (http://www.ebay.es/itm/281052578779?euid=7cfc8f92cf6d4907ae03ec94cc53957f&cp=1)
    • Voltage Regulator (http://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/lm1117-n.pdf)
    • Regulator and charger. It manages the power supply, it has been extracted from an external battery for smartphones. (An example is http://www.dx.com/p/universal-3-7v-10400mah-portable-external-li-ion-18650-battery-power-bank-blue-378112#.Va54LOSlilM)
    • Switch (internal battery/charging/external power)
    • [Optional] Xbee explorer dongle (it is the manner more comfortable to program the Arduino on board Bluetooth Bee Standalone http://xbee.cl/xbee-explorer-dongle/)

Recipe Instructions

  1. Print: 2 pieces of Snowflake_p1.stl, 2 pieces of Snowflake_p2.stl, 4 pieces of Snowflake_p3.stl, 2 pieces of Snowflake_tap.stl and 2 pieces of Snowflake_sphere.stl.

  2. Remove excess material and polish each piece, especially the joint areas.

  3. Assemble the snowflake sheets with glue. A good idea is to have two parts in order to access quickly to the electronic sphere. You can see it in the last pictures.

  4. Connect the electronic components like in the picture. If someone of you want a detailed schema, please ask!

  5. Program the Bluetooth Bee module with our software and install the Android application. The link will be published soon.

  6. Close the snowflake with the help of the covers.

  7. Fun it!

Performed iterations

  • How to split the snowflake for a good printing and assembly?
    First, the snowflake sheets were designed to be symmetry (all pieces equals) and with male and female parts to assemble it properly. But the snowflake sheets needed a lot of material support.
    Then, a new design was necessary prioritizing the best printing but without losing a perfect assembly. It is the uploaded version.

Future work

  • Design of a way of power off without disassembling the snowflake. For example, it will be possible doing a hole or cover in the internal sphere of the snowflake. => DONE ready to print the new internal sphere.
  • Implementation of more light effects. It implicates modifications in the Arduino program and the Android application. => DONE, I have to upload a new video.
  • Design a structure for the internal components of the lamp but the available space is small. Also, the battery connection could be improved.
  • Addition of the possibility of the bluetooth auto-connection to the last paired device (after power off) without doing the bluetooth association. Also, it is desirable to maintain the possibility to pair with new devices. It is necessary, for instance, when the user changes the smartphone. Two possible solutions:
  1. Using a new button to establish the bluetooth inquiring mode. By default, when the lamp is turned on, the bluetooth tries to connect to the last paired device. If it is needed to associate the lamp to a new device, the button should be pushed. This solution implicates hardware and software modifications.
  2. When the lamp is turned on, the bluetooth always tries to connect to the last paired device, if it fails (for example after 20 seconds), the bluetooth changes to inquiring mode. This solution implicates only Arduino program modifications. => DONE

title: Kossel Pro Spool Mount Adapter v2

description.text:
This is a spool mount adapter for the Kossel Pro. It attaches to an aluminum 1515 OpenBeam extrusion using two M3 x 6mm BHCS (or the longer M3 x 8mm SHCS) that are included in the Kossel Pro kit.

Version two of the original spool mount adapter adds two more mounting styles/orientations for different cold end positions (keeping the upright orientation, and adding two different side orientations).

Being just an mountable adapter, you'll need compatible spool holders, and these come in various shapes and sizes.

This has been tested with:

Customizable Spool Holder for Replicator 2

See the instructions for ideal print settings, and installation instructions.

Print settings

30% infill, .2 layers. Orient the print so that it is face down with the side holes
printed last.

Mounting hardware/instructions:

2x M3 x 6mm BHCS OR 2x M3 x 8mm SHCS

and

2x M3 nuts

Pre-threading things onto the adapter is recommended to take up any tolerances in printing,
as well as making the actual mounting easier.

Installation is best done with the printer on it's side. Insert the hex nuts,
and pre-insert the screws into the printed holder. Line everything up and secure with the appropriate driver.

description.text: This is a spool holder designed to allow the use of a 28mm spool on the Replicator 5th Generation. It is compatible with larger diameter spools as well.

Print 1 of each of the files.

We use about 25% infill for the Bracket and 50% for the Spindle.
The pins may require printing at a higher resolution, but the bracket and spindle print fine at .3mm.

To get a snug fit you may have to apply a couple pieces of tape to the spool holder as a spacer. This prints slightly larger than necessary to allow easier installation/removal.

Reuse of the stock guide tube is possible, the way the guide tube is held in the printer pinches the tube slightly so you may slightly damage your guide tube if not removed carefully.

title: Blackjack Playing Card Dealer Shoe (with optional expansion)

description.text:
Original design.

Can't believe this wasn't already made already! Needed a test of fit tolerances, and drew this dealing shoe model up and it fit the bill nicely.

Bottom plates should fit tightly and not slide around.

Top plates should be firm but slideable for easy removal.

Wedge should be printed separately, and as solid as it can be printed. Weight is important in pushing the cards forward!

Didn't have a deck of cards on hand when the pictures were taken and used a stack of business cards, but I have tested a deck of Cards Against Humanity cards in it and confirmed that they work BEAUTIFULLY!

I'm aware that the expansion is a tight fit. It's supposed to be that way. When assembling, try to avoid having to re-set the pieces together. You don't want to damage the jigsaw assembly nubs!

Model in the photos was printed on a Stratasys Fortus 250mc in Blue PLA.

Instructions are somewhat self explanatory. Use the included images to construct properly. Glue isn't necessary, but between the side plates and the bottom plates (inside the sliding groove) might help if you have trouble keeping them together.

This is a 3D model of the BoxPunx paper toys from a 3D printing class done for summer camp.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aU60ulkRjo2

This is a Makerbot printable Dan Moi*, which is similar to a Jew's Harp**. I modeled it off of a brass bass Dan Moi, but the sound is much closer to a bamboo one. While this will not replace a nice brass Dan Moi, you can print this on a well-tuned Makerbot! Here is a YouTube video of the Dan Moi in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=enHMpn5SC5w Since I can't seem to do links properly:
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_m%C3%B4i
    ** http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jews_harp

A well tuned machine should be able to print this out with no finishing. Depending on your tuning however, you may have to finish this a bit more to get the gap correct. I recommend carefully using an x-acto to get the extra bits off, and then finishing it with a very fine sandpaper. The tongue should move freely, but the gap should be minimal.
You play this like any other mouth harp. It should be touching your lips, and the tongue should be able to freely move. Pluck the end, and you should hopefully be making some sounds.

The result is a bulky unit with visible wires underneath it.

I designed a bezel to mount the unit behind a wall surface.
This model is made for 9mm wall in my camper van, but is easy to alter in 123d design

It consists of two parts;
part A - the main part
part B - an optional strip to cover the gap on top between the bezel and the charger. It can be glued to part A with glue (PLA) or acetone (ABS)

The charger unit can be crewed down on two wood blocks of 44mm high at the back of the wall panel.

UPDATE 08.08: Weeeell I did some CFD simulation since this design doesn't really blow.. It showed that this config of the profiles and the curve of the blades leads to sucking in air on both sides.. Well I'll try to post some updates asap to correct this problem.

UPDATE 23.07: I'll be away this weekend, but when I come back I'll post plans for the rest of the assembly (not my design, it actually came with a magazine), but it's only fair you get the chance to blow air in your face ;)

A working (actually blowing wind) fan I made. The picture is a small motor assembly my roommate had laying around. Since the motor isn't all too powerful, doesn't blow very far. Feel free to print it, it has a 4,5 hex hole on the bottom. Turning direction is clockwise.

For ABS:

Print with support (2mm rectilinear) and at least 10 lines of brim.
Preferably two perimeters and fill 100%. It takes about an hour at 25mm/s fill and outline. Print with the flat part of the head down (hex opening on the printbed).

Have fun!

**BONUS tray variation now available to download**

Based on my other wire baskets, this version was requested by Lofrank. It's designed to be printed at much larger sizes (the printed example is 160mm x 160mm x 80mm) Created in TopMod.

Supports will be required for the lower levels. Slow and thick is good for the bridging. This print took about 20 hours.

I finished mine by cleaning up the supports and any stringing from the overhangs. Then I sand it with increasingly fine sandpaper, ending up with a 3000 grit polishing cloth.

author: Bondeus

description.text:
The Sydney Opera House spectral structure I visited while with my cousins. It takes your breath away from a distance, but is even more magnificent when your visit it. It is hard to imagine how some architect visualized such an abstract structure, and even hard to think how it was built. It has a very original and creative design, and I wanted to capture it. It is one of the most amazing man made marvels of the world, and I am excited to present this model.

Printed on a prusa i3 Einstein from "Marko's Hub" check out skp images of my new work in progress prototype.

The curves of the roof tops had to be developed in a creative way, as the were taken as slices of an oval sphere, and matched to the shape of the actual opera house. I tool my pieces and compared it to an existing google earth model. The google earth model itself could not be used because it had too many internal structures and hidden geometry, and printing it failed, so I had to design my own model.
The rest of the model model was quite difficult to construct. Originally, it though I could just connect the rooftops and make one solid model, but I was so wrong. I forgot the pieces in between and the one solid model also failed. Therefore, I had to copy the roof and make another shell, so now the roof actually had thickness and could print instead of just being lines. Then I tried to make the base of the structure as the original Sydney Opera House, but that failed. I have temporarily just used a circle as a base because other people in who have made an opera house model did so too, but am working on a more realistic base for the structure.

Through this experience I have learned a lot about 3D modelling and new softwares, not to mention numerous new techniques. I hope you enjoy my adaptation of the Sydney Opera House, and watch out for updates in the future.

Tips: Use the highest resolution available on your printer
Scale the size as you wish
NO supports or rafts are require.

Getting this opera house is a simple process

  1. Download
  2. Go to your printing software and open the design
    Make sure to LAY FLAT and ON PLATFORM.
  3. Press print and you are ready to go! Enjoy!

author: WPLJoe

description.text:
I needed a small display for my fridge, but couldn't find the perfect one (besides in some places these are damn expensive) and I wondered how a printed seven segment display would work? The answer is that the printed display works very sweet!

As an extra bonus notice in the openscad code that I adapted most of the led sizes based on a logaritmic and quadratic formula (to define the led height and flange size based on the diameter) rather than hard-coding every set of parameters, quite nice eh?

Customize the module, fit your leds (no glue needed but you could block the back residual light with some dark silicone,), connect all the anodes or cathodes and use as an off the shelf module, enjoy!

For an added bonus stack them to create a larger display.

The diffuser layer is just a thin printed layer that should allow light to pass thru (and the extra one is just in case the leds emit a very focalized point of light).

In my actual thingomatic printer the 0.3 layer height generates 1 layer of plastic (perfect translucency) but check your own slicer/printer limits to get a nice print.

I've been flying these for over a year and whilst the market is now flooded with these racing quads, I figured it might still be an attractive option to anybody who wants an easy route into the game with an airframe that can be easily repaired with home-printed components!

The airframe is light and pretty agile (even on 3S!) if you keep the components down. The offset motor positions are similar to a well known and popular 450 size quad - they reduce yaw rate but induce some pitch at the same time as roll (or something like that). Seems to work well enough.

The frame is robust but designed to break in a hard crash - having said that, it has survived 20ft drops, cartwheels across fields, and even full-throttle smashes into an antique millstone (don't ask!)

The arms can be replaced in minutes in the event of a crash and the multi-part design gives more options for customisation. Go nuts!

Printer settings

I print mine at 0.2mm layer height, 0.48 extrusion width, 2 perimeters, 5 horizontal perimeters and 20% rectilinear infill with my stock Mendel90. You can increase the infill to make the parts stronger - at the expense of lightness.

Parts list

Print the following:
1x main deck
2x other decks
4x arms (plus spares if you wish!)

Vitamins

You will additionally need the following non-printable components:
4x M3 nuts
4x M3x10 button head screws
6x M3x20 button head screws
6x M3x8 button head screws
6x M3x8 lower deck threaded spacers
6x M3x25 upper deck threaded spacers
4x 5" props
plus electronics.

You can use either hex of circular profile spacers. The stock 25mm upper deck clearance is designed for the Mobius HD camera and a Zippy Compact 3S 1300mAH LiPo but if you need more space between the decks then just get bigger spacers (you might need longer screws as a result). You might want to swap the battery to the top deck and move other components down if you go large, as the weight distribution will probably be wrong.

Assembly

Assembly instructions are in the gallery - it's pretty straightforward but if you get the order wrong then the arms won't be as easy to fit or replace. The stock decks are identical top and bottom, but the variations (see below) will make them non-interchangeable.

The one in the photo runs on a KK2 flight controller, TS5823 VTx, ZMR 1804 motors, 10A ESCs and 5x3 props. I also have one that runs a Naze32, EMAX 2204 motors, Afro 12A ESCs and 6x4.5 props. They fly very differently.

Variations

I've included STLs for arms that accommodate the two most common motor mounting patterns - 22xx motors tend to have standard 16-19mm mounting holes, whereas some 18xx motors have 12-14mm mounting holes.

The top deck variations include diversity antenna holders and a single VTx antenna (such as the one that comes with the AttitudeRC 25mW transmitter.

I've also included the combined KK flight controller and TS5832 VTx housing. This was one of the cheapest ways of getting up and running when I originally designed this airframe but there are many more options now - I recommend a Naze32 or CC3D.

Back when I designed this one it was still common to print a separate FC case and stick it down - probably because there was no standard FC size. There are loads of Naze cases here on Thingiverse or you could just stick it down with servo tape.
comments.author: weepee14

comments.text: Hi there,
comments.author: mvcorrea

comments.text: The angle of the arms plays very little part in the aerodynamics of the airframe. The position of the motors is what affects the flight characteristics. Many of the newer flight controllers that are designed for racing expect the motors to be in a square formation - any deviation from this causes the yaw, pitch and roll response to be affected. In some cases the PIDs over-compensate and actually induce oscillation. Older, customisable flight controllers may be more suited for custom motor layouts.

comments.text: Yes, that's a frequently used diagram - it shows the difference between centre of thrust and centre of gravity, which are different things, especially on asymmetric frames (and are often confused by many).

Just got the first fly of this quad in last week, flew great, the abs arms at 25% infill were a bit too weak, they seemed to flex badly at full throttle and i've since replaced them with 30% ones, and since then haven't had an issue, including crashing fairly heavily twice. the quad handles well even in my inexperienced hands. i've found it comes in just shy of 500 grams ready to fly, without a gopro on it. Thank you heaps for the design. its been a pleasure to make.

comments.text: Hi, thanks for the support and sorry for the delay in replying. When I designed this quad the KK2 board was very cheap and offered an easy way to control a multirotor for the newcomer to this type of model. Since then a lot of better flight controllers have come along and I'm afraid I haven't kept this design up-to-date to accommodate them. Most FCs now fit on a 37mm square PCB, so adding some mounting holes is probably all I'd need to do.

This is a Filament Guide for a Felix 3d printer.

Designed to print flex, but ended up a universal extruder. The filament has no other way 2 go but down. It ended up a very fast, accurate problemless system. works as direct drive, or push-extruder. Available on i.materialise in Stainless steel https://i.materialise.com/shop/designer/3d-printersvdb

We needed an extruder system that would allow us too print flex, without ANY problem. And preferably one that could handle some speed. Since there is none existant without a problem of any kind, we made our own. We Sketched the prototype in Sketchup, printed it, and it worked, but the plastic could not resist the direct-drive-hotend-heat. so we made an aluminum one, wich needed an extra fan too cool off, cause aluminium is not quite heat resistant and the hotend heated the flexstruder, wich heated the PTFE guiding tube, Wich heated the filament, wich expanded and blocked itself. After an online search 4 the heat resistance of metals, we opted for Inox (stainless steel)
the problem of our flex filament expanding in the flextruder level of the design because of the heat, dissapeared without the need for an extra fan. the flexstruder was cold enough, while In use.
Using the Flexstruder as a Push extruder like Ultimaker or Reprap's solves all issue's above, and lightens the printhead.

Available on i.materialise in Stainless steel: https://i.materialise.com/shop/designer/3d-printersvdb

-spring, flex resistor, or wrinkled washers.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cmD5XZ4AQ4M

Print two of these to hang your spools off of a beam, such as hanging from a cabinet. This can comfortably house 10 or so spools without any problems structurally.

This was the first iteration I made and is good enough for my purposes. It is indeed overkill in terms of thickness. Total print time for two hangers is 6 hours on my printer.

This thing is for mounting a D-Link DCS-903L webcam on a MakerBot Replicator 2. It is is optimized to get a good total view of the build chamber. You can get a good impression when you watch its live output: http://www.web-n-apps.net/makerbot

I printed it with the standard medium settings (2 sheiks, 10% infill). There is also a version with (quite large) helper disks, as I had some issues with the mount bending up from the build plate.  
To install the mount, just remove the top middle hex screw on your replicator's front and put it through the mount and tighten the screw again. Remove the webcam from its desktop stand (silver nut) and install it on the mount. I like to install it up side down. Don't forget to activate the upside down flag in the webcam's image settings.

description.text:
This model just won't stay down! The top is hollow and light, but the bottom is heavy enough to make sure that the egg will always return to its upright position.

Print this egg at 85% - 100% infill, without supports. This model works best with a .4mm nozzle.

Check out this blog post to see our design process.

This part is already shelled for a .4mm nozzle. You should print it at the highest infill percentage you can. Depending on your printer's calibration, this can be anywhere from 85-100%.

The egg models should be printed in the default orientation for best results.

Cupboard door knobs with screw hole

Version 2 should be fine for printing, and has a curved top.

Version 3 should also print fine, is more customisable (i.e. height can also be adjusted), but has a flat top. The flat top should look good without additional post-cleaning on layered 3D printers (which suffer from quantisation with small angles).

The flat handle is a request from my aunt and uncle, who were having trouble finding an art-deco cupboard handle.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/26oQwpVlchN

Banana Stand
====
There's always money in this banana stand!
This banana stand includes a handy coin slot to so that there is always money in it. Works equally well with both left- and right-handed bananas. The coin slot holds about tree fiddy.

I printed this using a somewhat translucent yellow PLA. The banana model includes built-in support for the top of the coin slot. This gives you the option of either cutting it out after printing to use as a bank, or you could even drop some coins in the slot while it is printing to ensure that there is always money in your banana stand. The slot in the banana and the slot in the base that holds the banana upright make for a lot of bridges in this print; your temperatures, speeds, and fans should be well-calibrated if you want good results. You should be able to fit both of these on a standard 200x200mm plate. Designed in SketchUp, sliced with Slic3r using these settings: ; generated by Slic3r 0.9.8 on 2013-05-23 at 19:08:15 ; layer_height = 0.2
; perimeters = 3
; top_solid_layers = 3
; bottom_solid_layers = 3
; fill_density = .15
; perimeter_speed = 30
; infill_speed = 60
; travel_speed = 130
; scale = 1
; nozzle_diameter = 0.35
; filament_diameter = 2.9718
; extrusion_multiplier = 1
; perimeters extrusion width = 0.52mm
; infill extrusion width = 0.52mm
; first layer extrusion width = 0.70mm

title: 2x 3.5" HDD to 1x 5.25" ODD HP MicroServer Adapter

description.text:
The HP Microserver is a powerful, inexpensive, compact server tower that typically supports 4 Drives in the Bottom Bays, but with 2 PCI-e card slots available on the motherboard, the computer is capable of connecting many more HDD's.

Most people have used a Nexus Doubletwin, but looking at the price, lack of modification, shipping time / prices, I decided to design my own bracket. You can optionally use O-Rings, or insulated standoffs of some sort to minimize vibration from the disks (Home Depot / Lowes)

Mine came out to about $1.60 for both halves, and the bracket uses the HP Microserver’s included ODD Screws on the hinged door. (15% Infill Hexagonal, 3 bottom, 4 top, 3 perimeters, PLA) This is much cheaper than other comparable alternatives! If I've saved you time or money on your build and you'd like to donate:

I designed this a little while ago, just got around to posting it, I believe it’s a 5mm gap between thick hard drives. I used 3 TB Drives in the pictures, which are 3 platter disks. They’re pretty thick, so this bracket should fit most, if not all, hard drives. My measurements are in the pictures as well if anybody would like to check theirs.

Pictured on my MicroServer, I have 4 Drives in the bottom bays, 2 in the top bays, and a 2.5” OS drive from an older laptop underneath the ODD Bay. Totaling 6 Data disks, and 1 OS Disk. I have two cards on the HP Proliant pictured above: 

 1. Syba 2-Port USB 3.0 and 2-Port SATA III PCIe 2.0 x4 SD_PEX50055 Green, Grey from Amazon ($40.01). I use this on the full size PCI-e channel on the outboard edge of the motherboard.   

 2. VANTEC 4-Port SuperSpeed USB 3.0 PCIe Host Card Model UGT-PC341 from Newegg (24$). I use this one on the smaller size PCI-e channel on the inboard edge of the motherboard.

Using these two cards I have support for 6x External USB 3.0 Disks, 6x Internal 3.5” Data Disks, 1x2.5” OS Disk, 1x ESATA Disk, and 6x USB 2.0 Disks. This gives me ~ 12 Full Speed Data Disks before I need up upgraded cases / systems.

I recommend upgrading to the latest modded BIOS so you get full performance on the on-board SATA port on the Motherboard. Also uploading the 2.5” OS HDD Under ODD Tray I designed.

Any questions please feel free to message me!

-Sibobby1

As mentioned in the Description, I used 3mm PLA from Ultimachine, I believe I used 3 Perimeters, 3 Bottom Layers, 4 Top Layers ( I don't have a fan), 15% Hexagonal Infill.

  1. Print Part using Above / Similar Settings that work for your printer.
  2. Take out ODD Screws from the Door Included with MicroServer
  3. Self-Thread into the smaller holes on the bracket.
  4. Screw One side onto drives entirely (4 or 6 Screws, M3 Size, or ones included on door)
  5. Screw on other size, be sure circuit board doesn't hit metal lid on other drive. Bracket should support full weight cantilevered but just in case.
  6. Slide into ODD tray on HP MicroServer Proliant N40L / N54L (Not sure if compatible with other models, its a standard 5.25" tray )
  7. If you're worried about snapping / ease the bracket / assembly by pulling the ODD Release Trigger back making the drives slide in with less pressure. I redesigned the bracket 3-4 times, after I had a few snaps, but this is a STRONG / STURDY bracket now. very very strong. I'm sure it will hold up just fine.
  8. Post Thanks / Post your builds, Let me know of any modifications or ideas, check out my build, leave a comment, or a donation if I saved you time or money on your build :P

Thanks guys
Have fun, enjoy the server.
